title: 110_hr3717
content: The "Healthy Workforce Act of 2007" may be cited as the official title of this Act. It includes findings related to workforce health. Congress finds that effective worksite policies and programs can improve the health and safety of the 135 million workers in the United States, who spend a significant portion of their day on the job. Chronic diseases like heart disease, stroke, cancer, obesity, and diabetes are prevalent among workers, making it crucial for employers to implement strategies to reduce health risks and enhance the quality of life for their employees. Implementing effective worksite policies and programs can improve the health and safety of workers, leading to increased productivity and reduced healthcare costs for businesses. Tax credit available to employers for implementing wellness programs under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit available to employers for implementing wellness programs is determined as 50% of the costs paid or incurred by the employer in connection with a qualified wellness program during the taxable year, with a limit based on the number of employees. A qualified wellness program consists of 3 wellness components and must be certified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The program must be consistent with research and best practices to be certified. The wellness program must be evidence-based, include multiple strategies based on research, and focus on employee populations with health problems. The program must be periodically updated and reviewed by the Secretary. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish procedures for periodic review and updating of wellness programs to ensure compliance with requirements and reflect new scientific findings. Additionally, employees are encouraged to make programs culturally competent and meet the health literacy needs of covered individuals. The wellness program components include a health awareness component with health education and screenings, as well as an employee engagement component with an active committee to engage employees in worksite wellness programs. The worksite wellness program includes worksite assessments, program planning, delivery, evaluation, and tracking of employee participation. It also has a behavioral change component focusing on altering employee lifestyles through counseling, seminars, online programs, and self-help materials addressing tobacco use, obesity, stress management, physical fitness, nutrition, substance abuse, depression. The worksite wellness program includes a supportive environment component with policies promoting a healthy lifestyle, including tobacco use, nutrition, stress management, and mental health promotion. It also emphasizes accessible and attractive stairs. The worksite wellness program promotes a healthy lifestyle with policies on tobacco use, nutrition, stress management, and mental health. It also encourages physical activity before, during, and after work hours, offering participation incentives for health screenings and behavioral change programs. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, in coordination with the Secretary of Health and Human Services, must certify that all wellness program components apply to qualified employees for any credit to be allowed. Employee participation in managing qualified wellness programs is also emphasized. The Secretary of Health and Human Services prescribes rules for employers to provide specialized programs for employees with specific health needs or pilot wellness strategies. A qualified employee works at least 25 hours per week. The definition of employee includes partners in partnerships. The partnership rules under section 52 apply to costs incurred by an employer for food or health insurance, which are not included in the wellness program tax credit. No credit is allowed for a wellness program if the taxpayer receives a grant for it. The tax credit for a qualified wellness program constitutes a significant portion of funding. The credit period is defined as a 10 consecutive taxable year period, or 3 consecutive years for existing programs. The Secretary may provide exceptions for employers required to make substantial changes. The tax credit for a qualified wellness program is a significant funding source, with a credit period of 10 consecutive taxable years or 3 consecutive years for existing programs. Employers may be eligible for increased credits if substantial modifications are needed to qualify for certification as a qualified wellness program. Controlled groups are treated as a single employer for this purpose. The tax credit allowed under this subsection is based on the increase in credits without regard to section 38(c) for employer payroll taxes. Eligible employers are defined as State or political subdivisions. The tax credit allowed under this subsection is based on the increase in credits without regard to section 38(c) for employer payroll taxes. Eligible employers are defined as State or political subdivisions, the District of Columbia, possessions of the United States, agencies, instrumentalities, or organizations exempt from taxation under section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Employer payroll taxes refer to specific taxes imposed by sections 3111(b), 3211(a), and 3221(a). The tax credit for wellness programs is subject to termination after December 31, 2017. It is treated as a general business credit under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 280C of the Code denies a double benefit for certain expenses, including the wellness program credit. The tax credit for wellness programs is subject to termination after December 31, 2017. No deduction is allowed for costs of a qualified wellness program equal to the credit allowable under section 45O. If the credit exceeds the deduction, the capital account expenses are reduced by the excess amount. Controlled groups are subject to specific rules. The tax credit for wellness programs may be terminated after December 31, 2017. If the credit exceeds the deduction, the excess amount reduces capital account expenses for controlled groups. The tax credit for wellness programs may be terminated after December 31, 2017. An outreach program will be implemented to inform businesses about the wellness program credit and educate them on developing and measuring program success. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this outreach program.
